{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3481635,"name":"Gerardo","username":"jerry.origin","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/jerry.origin/{size}/253430_2.png","created_at":"2025-01-14T01:58:41.366Z","cooked":"

Hi, my team and I are looking to make an elevator but it seems that all of the elevators to buy are out of stock and they will be in stock until mid January, we don’t think we can wait that long since we have our competition at the end of February so we are looking to make the elevator ourselves, I mainly made this CAD, took a lot of inspiration of other elevators mainly the one from thethriftybot.com, I would like to know if this design is viable and possible to make, this is technically my second year in FRC, but last year I was only into programming and now I am getting more into mechanics so many stuff is pretty new to me.

cad.onshape.com

Onshape

Sign in to Onshape, the #1 fastest growing CAD system in the world with over 4 million users.

","post_number":1,"post_type":1,"posts_count":8,"updated_at":"2025-01-14T01:58:41.366Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":115,"reads":406,"readers_count":405,"score":656.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":481554,"topic_slug":"feedback-on-elevator-design","display_username":"Gerardo","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://cad.onshape.com/documents/ab12845e82bfab5f0387fc3f/w/53c85b1b771120d1992a6a68/e/2708e2cb2f327c53fb1b3561?renderMode=0&uiState=6785c46aea8a3b3358557f93","internal":false,"reflection":false,"title":"Onshape","clicks":108},{"url":"http://thethriftybot.com","internal":false,"reflection":false,"title":"FRC Robotics Parts & Solutions | Affordable Off-the-Shelf Components","clicks":23}],"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":66640,"hidden":false,"trust_level":1,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Lead Programmer"},"post_url":"/t/feedback-on-elevator-design/481554/1","custom_user_title":"Lead Programmer","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null,"can_vote":false},{"id":3481803,"name":"usbcd36","username":"usbcd36","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/usbcd36/{size}/2444_2.png","created_at":"2025-01-14T04:53:22.289Z","cooked":"

The difficult parts in this elevator are the chain-to-tube mounts and the bearing blocks. The trouble is, TTB is sold out of the bearing blocks.

Edit: SDS isn’t sold out of their elevator bearing kits; they have a 5-day lead time, though. These are probably better than the old VEX stuff.

Deprecated

If you can manufacture the blocks and buy the bearings, you’re probably home free. If not, you’ll need to do something else. The old VEX linear slide kits aren’t the best, but the parts were entirely made of sheet metal and spacer stock and thus very easy to manufacture. They will limit your travel more than any of the modern billet blocks, unfortunately, since the fore/aft and side-to-side bearings have to be offset vertically.

Pulleys for the second stage should be obtainable, or 3D printable. You don’t necessarily need forks like The Thrifty Elevator uses; the pulleys can be set with their axle bolts through the tubes instead. That said, the rope runs take up less space if you can get or make forks (probably from someone other than TTB).

As far as the remainder of the design goes, you’ll need to ensure the chain run that is clamped to the first stage runs parallel to that stage. In the CAD you linked, the chain is farther away at the top than at the bottom, which will cause it to try to rip the top chain mounts off of the elevator as you raise it.

How could we make the blocks? Also could you explain a bit more on what you mean about the pulleys please, am a bit confused.

","post_number":3,"post_type":1,"posts_count":8,"updated_at":"2025-01-14T13:14:19.424Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":2,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":3,"reads":243,"readers_count":242,"score":68.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":481554,"topic_slug":"feedback-on-elevator-design","display_username":"Gerardo","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"reply_to_user":{"id":7334,"username":"usbcd36","name":"usbcd36","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/usbcd36/{size}/2444_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":66640,"hidden":false,"trust_level":1,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Lead Programmer"},"post_url":"/t/feedback-on-elevator-design/481554/3","custom_user_title":"Lead Programmer","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3482002,"name":"usbcd36","username":"usbcd36","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/usbcd36/{size}/2444_2.png","created_at":"2025-01-14T13:54:18.363Z","cooked":"

First off, if you haven’t already, check out this video: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=rICU4XyNPAU

If you want to build an elevator similar to it, you’ll need all of these parts, or equivalents.

I strongly recommend buying some sort of elevator bearing block – whether it be SDS, GreyT, REV, new-REV, or something else. Out-of-stock doesn’t mean out-of-stock forever. Only machine something if you have to. I’m not sure what your team’s manufacturing capabilities are, so I can’t say for sure whether you’ll have a difficult time creating elevator bearing blocks. I definitely would use a tested design, though; I would not create your own from scratch. The bearing blocks used in The Thrifty Elevator require double-sided machining and a ballnose endmill. If you have a CNC mill, these might be possible to make; if you have just a CNC router like most FRC teams, it would be much more difficult.

Here’s what the bearing blocks (ELEV-SLIDE-001) look like:

Again, it would be no problem if you could buy them, but they don’t seem to be available right now.

The CAD you posted doesn’t include the pulleys necessary to make the carriage of your elevator move. You will need to add pulleys and rigging similar to The Thrifty Elevator (or GreyT elevator) in order to make it work. I am referring to ELEV-PULLEY-002 and ELEV-PULLEY-004 in this photo:

Check out the video, the part beginning around 31:23, for more details.

The school where my team is located has some machines, though I would need to check if they are the ones you are talking about, right now our goal is to complete the robot design and most of the construction before the end of the month, because we have a reputation of completing it the last week before the competition, this is the main reason we don’t wish to wait for the parts to be in stock again.

Yeah about the carriage, I don’t know if its possible but, we don’t know for sure if we want to use a carriage or we will just attach our “Coral Manipulator” to the elevator without a carriage. On the CAD the Manipulator its supposed to be directly attached to the elevator without a carriage, at least for now.

","post_number":5,"post_type":1,"posts_count":8,"updated_at":"2025-01-14T14:06:56.335Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":4,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":164,"readers_count":163,"score":42.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":481554,"topic_slug":"feedback-on-elevator-design","display_username":"Gerardo","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"reply_to_user":{"id":7334,"username":"usbcd36","name":"usbcd36","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/usbcd36/{size}/2444_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":66640,"hidden":false,"trust_level":1,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Lead Programmer"},"post_url":"/t/feedback-on-elevator-design/481554/5","custom_user_title":"Lead Programmer","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3482023,"name":"usbcd36","username":"usbcd36","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/usbcd36/{size}/2444_2.png","created_at":"2025-01-14T14:20:57.463Z","cooked":"

Ah, sounds like you mean a single-stage elevator. The last stage is usually still “the carriage”, regardless of the number of stages. However, you wouldn’t need the ropes.

Regarding design and parts availability, design for what you can get. For example the GreyT elevator stuff is mostly in-stock. I’d go for that over machining your own; much easier. The only parts out-of-stock are the rope (which you may not need) and the aluminum tube (which you can probably find elsewhere).

Thanks for the clarification on it being a single-stage! In this is it best to use chain than rope?

Also there is something I am still having trouble understanding and that is how you calculate the gearbox ratio you need for this elevator, for now I put it as a 1:12 Gear ratio (1:4 and 1:3 Gearbox) using a NEO, would this be fine or do I need to calculate it depending on the weight, and also if I need to use one or two NEOs, I see that the TTB elevator uses two while the andymark uses only one. Whats the main difference?

Going what @usbcd36 which is all valid advice. You can use chain; you just need a sound way of attaching the chain to your stages. You can do it the way TTB does it which is to run two chains with the two motors separate. Or you can run it down the middle like WCP Grey T to an output shaft. I am going to link this discussion because they link calculators you can use to find an ideal gear ratio. 12:1 with two Neos might be a good start.
